rsbNotes.title: Ps 28:1
rsbNotes.text:
28:1 my rock. Using this familiar name the psalmist remembers God as his source of protection and strength (Deut. 32:4, 18, 31; Ps. 78:35).

go down to the pit. That is, to die. The pit stands for Sheol, the grave (6:5 note).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 28:2
rsbNotes.text: 28:2 holy sanctuary. The Most Holy Place, the inner room in the tabernacle or temple where the ark of the covenant stood.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 28:3
rsbNotes.text: 28:3 speak peace. The psalmist knows the hypocrisy of his enemies.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 28:4
rsbNotes.text: 28:4 render them. An imprecation, that is, a prayer that God would punish the enemy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 28:5
rsbNotes.text: 28:5 he will tear them down. The previous verse appealed for judgment and this one pronounces it.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 28:9
rsbNotes.text:
28:9 your people. The psalmist broadens his appeal to the Lord to include the whole nation.

Be their shepherd. See note Ps. 23:1.
